etymologies: late Middle English (denoting the rootstock of other plants of this genus used medicinally): from Old French reubarbe, from a shortening of medieval Latin rheubarbarum, alteration (by association with rheum ‘rhubarb’) of rhabarbarum ‘foreign rhubarb’, from Greek rha (also meaning ‘rhubarb’) + barbaros ‘foreign’

definitions: the thick leaf stalks of a cultivated plant of the dock family, which are reddish or green and eaten as a fruit after cooking
shortDefinitions: thick reddish or green leaf stalks of cultivated plant of dock family

definitions: the large-leaved Eurasian plant which produces rhubarb.
shortDefinitions: large-leaved Eurasian plant which produces rhubarb

definitions: used in names of other plants of the sane genus as rhubarb, several of which are used medicinally, e.g., Chinese rhubarb.
shortDefinitions: used in names of other plants of this genus

definitions: the noise made by a group of actors to give the impression of indistinct background conversation or to represent the noise of a crowd, especially by the random repetition of the word “rhubarb” with different intonations.
shortDefinitions: noise made by group of actors to give impression of indistinct background conversation

examples.text: rhubarbs often broke out among these less than professional players
